data.sampled:
The maximum potential gain of this combination of puts and calls would be $24 if the stock price on the expiration date is exactly equal to the stock price specified by each option's strike price (i.e., either $380 or $396). In order to achieve this gain, both options must have intrinsic value on their respective expiration days, meaning that they must be "in-the-money." Specifically, if the stock price on the expiration day of the first put is between $380 and $387.5, then it will be considered "at-the-money," which means that its intrinsic value will be zero and therefore the total gain will also be zero. If the stock price on the expiration day of the second put is between $387.5 and $396, then it will be considered "out-of-the-money" because it has no intrinsic value and can only earn or lose money based on time decay. However, since there is still time remaining until the expiration date, even out-of-the-money options may experience some increase in value due to changes in volatility and/or changes in interest rates.

The minimum potential loss of this combination of puts and calls would be $469 ($4.69 + $6.93) plus any applicable commission fees. This amount represents the sum of the premiums paid for each option, and reflects the most that could potentially be lost if none of these options were exercised before their expirations. Of course, given enough time, most options do tend to lose value as they approach their expirations, so it is likely that this minimum potential loss could actually turn into a realized loss if no action was taken prior to the options' expirations. data.sampled:
The maximum potential profit (gain) can be calculated by finding the difference between the stock price and the option's strike price plus any premium received when selling options minus the premium paid when buying options. To calculate the maximum potential profit of each transaction individually, you would subtract the premium received/paid from the strike prices as follows:

Max Gain - Sell $70 Strike Price Put = Max(($70 + Premium Received), ($73 - Premium Paid))
Max Gain - Buy $73 Strike Price Put = Max(($73 + Premium Paid), ($70 - Premium Received))
Max Gain - Sell $77 Strike Price Call = Max(($77 - Premium Received), ($74 - Premium Paid))
Max Gain - Buy $73 Strike Price Call = Max(($73 + Premium Paid), ($77 - Premium Received))
The minimum potential loss can be calculated similarly but looking at the opposite scenario where the asset will lose value. Minimum Potential Loss = Asset Stock Price – Option Strike Price – Premium Paid (if any). This means that the total possible losses for all transactions would be:
Min Losses = Max(($70 - $73), ($73 - $77), ($77 - $73), ($73 - $70)) = Max(-$3, -$4, -$4, -$3)

= $380 - $0.0469 = $379.9531

For the bought put option with a strike price of $387.5 and a premium of $6.93:
Break-even stock price = Strike Price + Premium/Number of Shares

= $387.5 + $0.0693 = $394.4697

Given the expiration dates are the same and no other investments are owned, what is the breakeven stock price(s) for the following? Sell 1 $100 strike price put at $0.1. Buy 1 $175 strike price put at $8.18. Sell 1 $200 strike price call at $3.55. Buy 1 $175 strike price call at $13.7.

data.sampled:
The breakeven stock prices can be calculated as follows:
For the sold put options, subtracting the premium received ($2.23 per share) from the exercise price ($152.5 per share):
Break-even Price = Exercise Price - Premium Paid/Received = $152.5 - $2.23 = $149.87

For the bought put option, adding the premium paid ($6.28 per share) to the break-even price (which is the current stock price of $170 per share):
Break-even Price = Current Stock Price + Premium Paid = $170 + $6.28 = $176.28

For the sold call option, subtracting the premium received ($3.55 per share) from the exercise price ($200 per share):
Break-even Price = Exercise Price - Premium Paid/Received = $200 - $3.55 = $196.45

For the bought call option, adding the premium paid ($16.8 per share) to the break-even price (which is the current stock price of $170 per share):
Break-even Price = Current Stock Price + Premium Paid = $170 + $16.8 = $186.8

Therefore, the possible breakeven stock prices are:
[$149.87, $176.28, $196.45, $186.8]
